facts: In many homes, the refrigerator is one of the biggest energy users because it runs all day and night.
A simple way to save water at home is to fix a dripping faucet, since small drips can add up to many liters over time.
Carpet can trap dust, pollen, and pet dander, so regular vacuuming helps improve indoor air quality.
Most houseplants do not “make” extra oxygen at night because many plants release carbon dioxide after dark.
Smoke alarms should be tested regularly, and the batteries should be replaced when they get weak or at least once a year.
Keeping your thermostat a few degrees lower in winter or higher in summer can reduce heating and cooling costs.
Properly stored food lasts longer in airtight containers because less air and moisture reach it.
